meta.name: Description

head.title: Dynamic Transport Control of Colloidal Particles by Repeatable Active Switching of Solute Gradients | ACS Nano

meta.content: Dynamic Transport Control of Colloidal Particles by Repeatable Active Switching of Solute Gradients

Diffusiophoresis (DP) is described as typically being divided into chemiphoresis (CP) and electrophoresis (EP), and the related theory is well-established. However, not only the individual effect of CP and EP but also the size dependency on the resulting DP of colloidal particles has not yet been comprehensively demonstrated in an experimental manner. In this paper, we present a dynamic transport control mechanism for colloidal particles by developing a micro-/nanofluidic DP platform (MNDP). We demonstrate that the MNDP can generate transient and/or steady-state concentration gradients, making it possible to control the direction and rate of transport of colloidal particles through the individual manipulation of CP and EP by simply and rapidly switching solutions. In addition, the MNDP allows the size-dependent separation as well as fractionation of submicron particles through the individual manipulation of CP and EP, thus empirically validating the classic theoretical model for DP under the influence of electrical double layer (EDL) thickness. Furthermore, we provide theoretical analysis and simulation results that will enable the development of a versatile separation and/or fractionation technique for various colloidal particles, including biosamples, according to their size or electrical feature.

div.span: Supporting Info (10)
SUBJECTS:

div.p: Diffusiophoresis (DP) is described as typically being divided into chemiphoresis (CP) and electrophoresis (EP), and the related theory is well-established. However, not only the individual effect of CP and EP but also the size dependency on the resulting DP of colloidal particles has not yet been comprehensively demonstrated in an experimental manner. In this paper, we present a dynamic transport control mechanism for colloidal particles by developing a micro-/nanofluidic DP platform (MNDP). We demonstrate that the MNDP can generate transient and/or steady-state concentration gradients, making it possible to control the direction and rate of transport of colloidal particles through the individual manipulation of CP and EP by simply and rapidly switching solutions. In addition, the MNDP allows the size-dependent separation as well as fractionation of submicron particles through the individual manipulation of CP and EP, thus empirically validating the classic theoretical model for DP under the influence of electrical double layer (EDL) thickness. Furthermore, we provide theoretical analysis and simulation results that will enable the development of a versatile separation and/or fractionation technique for various colloidal particles, including biosamples, according to their size or electrical feature.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.div:
Most biosamples need to be preconcentrated,
(1,2)
separated,
(3,4)
and extracted
(5,6)
according to their features for specific purposes. The transport mechanisms of colloidal particles, which can be used as biosample models, have been widely studied in miniaturized systems called micrototal-analysis systems (μTASs).
(7,8)
Various phoresis mechanisms have been studied and applied to the transport control of colloidal particles on a chip, including electrophoresis (EP),
(9,10)
dielectrophoresis,
(8,11)
acoustophoresis,
(3,12)
optophoresis,
(13,14)
and thermophoresis.
(15,16)
These mechanisms are named based on the applied energy or power source they utilize, as they depend on external equipment or energy/power sources. More recently, diffusiophoresis (DP) has drawn significant attention as a promising means of particle transport control because it enables the spontaneous migration of colloidal particles by using an induced solute gradient.
(17−23)
DP is divided into chemiphoresis (CP) and EP. The solute gradient imposes an osmotic pressure gradient near the particle surface (i.e., CP) and an electric field driven by diffusivity difference of ions (i.e., EP).
(24,25)
Therefore, DP, in which EP and CP always compete with each other, can be applied for controlling the transport of most colloidal particles, including micro-/nanoparticles,
(22)
DNA,
(26,27)
and cells,
(28,29)
after electrical charging of their surfaces (i.e., inducing zeta potential ζ
p
).
(21,22)
However, it is still necessary to explore the DP mechanism for individual control of CP and EP of colloidal particles when their size is comparable to the electrical double layer (EDL) thickness. In addition, the existing approaches enabling DP-based particle transport control and their corresponding devices have several limitations, such as their reusability, operation time, and nonswitchable environment on demand, which can be largely attributed to the dead-end channel structure.
(21,22)

In this work, we developed a micro-/nanofluidic DP platform (MNDP) that can control long-term solute/concentration gradients without any pressure controllers and electrical power sources by integrating a cracking-assisted nanochannel with a microfluidic channel network. We then demonstrate that the MNDP can dynamically generate and temporally modify the physicochemical environment of the target chamber, making it possible to actively manipulate the DP-based transport of various colloidal particles. We also performed numerical simulations to study the effect of diffusioosmosis (DO) by the microfluidic channel walls on the particle transport in the presence of concentration gradients in a steady state. Finally, we demonstrate the separation and fractionation of particles according to size by individually controlling the magnitude and direction of CP and EP, empirically validating the theoretically driven, size-dependent DP mechanism for submicron particles.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
a illustrates a mixed-scale MNDP that can generate and maintain a stable concentration gradient for long-term DP assays on a chip. We adopted a batch microfabrication process by employing cracking-assisted photolithography
(31)
(i.e., crack-photolithography) and modified soft-lithography to fabricate a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS)-based MNDP in which a crack-nanochannel suppresses advection flow but promotes diffusive mass transport toward the target microchamber. The detailed process is described in the
Methods
section. The MNDP comprises two main channels connected with a microfluidic target chamber of 200 μm (length) × 50 μm (width) × 10 μm (height) and a cracking-assisted nanochannel (
L
= 5 μm). The top main channel is used to load colloidal particles with a low concentration (
c
L
); the bottom main channel is used as a source channel to load a salty solution with a high concentration (
c
H
).

div.p:
Figure 1. Concept, fabrication, and working mechanism of the hybrid-scale micro-/nanofluidic DP platform (MNDP). (a) Schematic of the MNDP in the production of a stable concentration gradient in the target chamber through a nanochannel. (b) Microscopic images of the MNDP filled with 1 mM of fluorescence dye. (c) Atomic force microscopic (AFM) image showing the morphology of the nanochannel. (d) Sequential fluorescence images of the DP-based concentration of colloidal particles in the presence of the concentration gradient of NaCl (
c
L
= 10 μM and
c
H
= 1 M). (e) Numerical simulation results show the side view of the particle motion in the presence of the concentration gradient.

div.div:
Figure
1
b shows the fabricated MNDP, in which the channel network including the nanochannel was visualized using a fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) solution, demonstrating that the nanochannel is stable and robust without fluid leakage.
Figure
1
c shows an atomic force microscope (AFM) image of a typical nanochannel, which is 2 μm wide and 190 nm deep near the bottom main channel. As such nanochannels have high hydraulic resistances compared to the neighboring microchannels, as shown in
Figure S1a
, the advection flow induced by the pressure difference is negligible. As shown in
Movie S1
, even under a high pressure difference between the two main channels, no colloidal particles entered the target chamber. However, the nanochannels are deep enough (∼200 nm) to transport all ions in a diffusive manner without exclusion by the overlapped EDL (EDL thickness κ
–1
= ∼3 nm,
c
= 10 mM).
(21,30)
Moreover, approximately 5 min was required to completely refresh the chemical environment of the target chamber by using an FITC solution, as shown in
Figure S1b,c
. We visualized the concentration gradient, quantified the fluorescence intensities (FIs), and demonstrated the rapid control of the physicochemical environment of the target chamber. In addition, nanochannels highly dilute the concentration of solutes owing to the small space, while accurately controlling the mass transfer in a diffusive manner; this is characterized by not only the use of fluorescence dye but also the simulation result of solute gradients, as shown in
Figures S2 and S3
, respectively. These nanochannel features facilitate the active regulation of a physicochemical environment in the target chamber by the simple loading of ionic solutions through a pipet.
(32)

Figure
1
d demonstrates the DP-based transport of negatively charged particles (carboxylated polystyrene with particle diameter
d
p
= 1 μm and measured zeta potential ζ
p
= −50 mV, as shown in
Table S1
) and their enrichment at the nanochannel entrance in the presence of the NaCl concentration gradient. Colloidal particles with a low concentration of NaCl (
c
L
= 10 μM) were loaded into the top main channel while those with high concentration of NaCl (
c
H
= 1 M) were loaded into the bottom main channel. This experimental condition produced a concentration gradient of NaCl across the target chamber. The introduction of the 1 μm carboxylated polystyrene (radius
a
= 500 nm) with a thin EDL thickness allowed us to apply a size-independent DP model (
κa
→ ∞). For this platform, CP leads to the inside of the target chamber because it always acts toward higher concentration. In addition, NaCl was used to induce an outward electric field because chloride ion (
D
Cl–
= 2.032 × 10
–9
m
2
/s) is higher in diffusivity than sodium ion (
D
Na+
= 1.334 × 10
–9
m
2
/s), resulting in β
NaCl
= −0.207. Furthermore, the introduction of the negatively charged particles caused EP to act toward the inside of the target chamber as well, resulting in particle accumulation. Although fluid advection, which is a diffusioosmotic flow, with opposite direction to the DP was also induced near the wall, this fluid flow only affects the particles near the wall, as shown in
Movie S2
.

We also conducted numerical simulations to acquire insights into the particle motion by individually tracing particles in the target chamber. The numerical simulation domain is presented in
Figure S4
, and the numerical method used is described in the
Supporting Information
.
Figure
1
e shows the side view of the target chamber in which colloidal particles were visualized with time. The particles were concentrated toward the nanochannel leftward in the presence of the concentration gradient of NaCl (
c
L
= 10 μM and
c
H
= 1 M). Interestingly, the circulating flows induced by DO not only migrated the particles toward the top and bottom side walls but also forced some particles to escape rightward from the nanochannel to the top main channel. This result is similar to those derived in recent studies in which major attention was given to DO in micro-/nanofluidic systems.
(33,34)
However, most particles are drawn toward the nanochannel on average because DO only significantly affects particles close to the wall, and the net flow rate is near zero at any cross section of the microchamber because of back pressure.
Movie S3
further confirms this simulation result from the top view of the target chamber. The simulation result showed good agreement with the experimental result. Further, the DP remained almost constant and a steady state in the target chamber, facilitating the long-term and stable accumulation of particles with respect to the concentration gradients of NaCl and KCl, as shown in
Figures S5 and S6
; this agrees well with the experimental results obtained in a previous study.
(20)

Figure
2
a shows the extraction mechanism of the negatively charged colloidal particles preconcentrated by DP. The accumulated particles are easily extracted by reversing the DP, which is performed by changing the physicochemical environment in the target chamber. First, distilled water is loaded into the top main channel to wash away redundant particles. Then, K-acetate is introduced along the bottom main channel to induce reverse DP. This occurs because potassium ions (
D
K+
= 1.957 × 10
–9
m
2
/s) are faster than acetate ions (
D
acetate–
= 1.089 × 10
–9
m
2
/s), thus producing an inward electric field (β
K-acetate
= 0.285) and causing negatively charged particles to migrate outward by EP. Although the direction of the CP remains inward because the total concentration is sustained, EP is dominant enough to change the direction of DP during the transient state because of the ionic interdiffusion phenomenon between NaCl and K-acetate, thus reinforcing the imposed electric field.
(22)
However, the effect of the ionic interdiffusion vanishes soon, and after the new concentration gradient is established, the competition between CP and EP determines the net DP direction in the steady state. Here, the diffusioosmotic flow significantly affects the migration direction of the individual particles by inducing circulation flows near the corner of the target chamber, as shown in the simulation results earlier.

div.p:
Figure 2. Simple and on-demand extraction of the preconcentrated colloidal particles. (a) Schematic of two stages of the extraction process: transient and steady states after buffer change. (b, c) Time-lapse fluorescence images of the DP-based extraction of the preconcentrated colloidal particles for 10 min in the presence of the concentration gradient of pure K-acetate (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 1 M) and K-acetate (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 1 M) mixed with 0.02% Pluronic F-127, respectively. (d) Analytical results show that the contributions of CP and EP to the size-independent Γ
p
of the colloidal particles can significantly change with the addition of Pluronic F-127 in the presence of the K-acetate concentration gradient because of the decrease in the ζ potential from ζ
p
= −53.5 to −17.3 mV. (e) The extraction ratio of the preconcentrated colloidal particles using the pure K-acetate levels off at 85% extraction ratio after 4 min, whereas for the K-acetate containing Pluronic F-127, the ratio exceeds 95% after 10 min.

div.div:
Figure
2
b shows the extraction results of the preconcentrated colloidal particles with the loading of K-acetate solution into the bottom main channel. We previously accumulated 1 μm carboxylated polystyrene for 2 h with the concentration gradient of NaCl. Then, we replaced the NaCl solution with a K-acetate solution (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 1 M) to reverse the net DP direction. Most preconcentrated colloidal particles were extracted within 5 min because of the EP-dominant condition during the transient state. For the steady state, however, the preconcentrated particles that escaped return to the target chamber and become trapped in the chamber corners because DP is comparable to the advection flow induced by DO near the wall. The entrapped colloidal particles form circulating motions near the corners in a similar fashion as stated earlier. To extract particles completely, the net Γ
p
should be larger than the diffusioosmotic mobility (Γ
w
) for the steady state; these mobilities can be adjusted by simply adding a surfactant to change the ζ potential of the particles.
Figure
2
c shows the extraction of preconcentrated colloidal particles under the same experimental condition but with the addition of Pluronic F-127 (0.02% w/v). In this case, many of the preconcentrated particles were extracted during the first 5 min, similar to the previous result with no surfactant. However, particles are continuously extracted even for the steady state in the presence of the same concentration gradient.

Figure
2
d shows the analytical result of the Γ
p
with K-acetate, which depends on the ζ potential of the particles. Typically, nonionic surfactants can reduce the ζ potential of colloidal particles by adsorption; this shifts the shear plane away from the colloidal-particle surfaces,
(35,36)
thereby changing their Γ
p
. As the ζ potential varies, the Γ
EP
changes linearly (red line) while the Γ
CP
changes nonlinearly (blue line). Thus, the net Γ
p
changes from −40 to −70 μm
2
/s as the ζ potential decreases from −53.5 mV (i.e., for the pure K-acetate) to −17.3 mV (i.e., for K-acetate containing 0.02% Pluronic F-127). As the motions of the particles near the wall are determined by DP and DO, we can predict the directions of the particles near the corners depending on the Γ
w
of the PDMS wall. However, the ζ potential of the PDMS wall and the resulting Γ
w
in the presence of a nonionic surfactant are not yet well-known because of the poor repeatability of experimental measurements. Thus, we conducted time-dependent 3D numerical simulations to confirm the extraction mechanism depending on the mobility difference between DP and DO by varying the ζ potential of the PDMS wall (
Movies S4 and S5
). As expected, a relatively strong diffusioosmotic flow (i.e., Γ
w
> Γ
p
) entraps preconcentrated particles near the corners of the target chamber whereas a relatively weak diffusioosmotic flow (i.e., Γ
w
< Γ
p
) does not influence the extraction.

Figure
2
e shows a comparison of the extraction performance based on the FIs of the preconcentrated particles in the target chamber over time. We measured the net FI after the preconcentration was completed (i.e., FI
net
) and then quantified the FIs of the remaining particles (FI
R
) in the target chamber, thereby calculating the extraction ratio as 1 – FI
R
/FI
net
. For pure K-acetate, the extraction ratio equilibrates to 85% after 4 min. However, for K-acetate with a surfactant, the extraction ratio is improved from 85% to 95%. This is because the outward net Γ
p
is enhanced by the surfactant addition, which facilitates not only the complete extraction of the preconcentrated particles but also the repeatable use of the MNDP.
Movie S6
shows the reusability test of the MNDP, and the MNDP was confirmed to avoid clogging problems with the assistance of the surfactant.

As a proof of concept,
Figure
3
shows the results of size-dependent separation and fractionation of particles, thereby demonstrating practical application of the MNDP. To minimize the effect of difference in ζ potential on the separation, we prepared a submicron particle mixture by using polystyrene composed of 200 and 620 nm particles and fluorescently labeled using Rhodamine-B (red) and DAPI (blue), respectively. The difference in ζ potential between the 200 nm (ζ
p
≈ −70 mV) and 620 nm (ζ
p
≈ −73 mV) particles considering size effect
(23)
is less than 3 mV, as shown in
Table S1
. The particle mixture was highly concentrated near the nanochannel entrance for 30 min by using a concentration gradient of NaCl (
c
L
= 10 μM and
c
H
= 1 M), as shown in
Figure S7
. Before the buffer change for the separation, we confirmed that self-diffusion induced by Brownian motion allows for both particle types to migrate toward low-concentration regions in the absence of concentration gradient of solutes (NaCl,
c
L
=
c
H
= 10 mM); however, the particles are not separated, as shown in
Movie S7
. Then, we tested three extraction conditions by using K-acetate, Na-acetate, and a mixture of these two solutions sequentially. First, we employed a concentration gradient of K-acetate (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 1 M), as shown in
Figure
3
a. Both particle types preconcentrated in advance were extracted mostly for the transient state (i.e., <5 min), in which an interdiffusional phenomenon is induced and dominant; the 200 nm particles move faster and farther than the 620 nm particles. However, for the steady state (i.e., >5 min), in which the other concentration gradient is newly established, some of the 620 nm particles that have migrated away from the nanochannel junction return to the target chamber and become entrapped again. This is because the diffusioosmotic flow, which is fully developed for the transient state and becomes dominant during the steady state, affects the net mobility of the particles. In other words, the diffusioosmotic flow causes the remaining particles in the target chamber to flow toward the nanochannel junction again, thus inducing the circulating motion of some particles in the target chamber. As a result, the 200 nm particles are completely extracted while most of the 620 nm particles are entrapped in the target chamber, demonstrating the partial separation of submicron particles according to size.

div.p:
Figure 3. Transport control of a submicron particle mixture comprising red fluorescent 200 nm and blue fluorescent 620 nm polystyrene particles. (a) The particle mixture, preconcentrated in advance, is separated by generating a K-acetate concentration gradient (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 1 M) that induces relatively strong EP compared to CP. (b) The particle mixture is fractionated according to size by generating the Na-acetate concentration gradient (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 1 M) that induces relatively weak electrophoresis. (c) A mixture of Na-acetate (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 800 mM) and K-acetate (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 200 mM) is exploited to selectively extract only the 200 nm particles for the transient state and then trap the 620 nm particles in the target chamber during the steady state.

div.div:
Second,
Figure
3
b shows the fractionation of particles with the concentration gradient of Na-acetate (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 1 M), which generates a relatively weak electric field compared to that of K-acetate because of the low diffusivity difference between ions (i.e., β
Na-acetate
= 0.101). For the transient state (i.e., <5 min), both particle types are extracted from the nanochannel junction in a similar manner to that shown in
Figure
3
a. However, the separation span seems narrower than that in the previous experiment (
Figure
3
a) approximately 2 min after the solution is switched. In the steady state (i.e., >5 min), the 200 nm particles that migrated farther during the transient state are forced to slowly return to the nanochannel junction. As the 620 nm particles form a close-packed structure, with a theoretical pore size of 93 nm (i.e., approximately 15% of the particle diameter),
(37)
they may prevent small particles from penetrating through the pores, thereby resulting in size-based particle fractionation.

Third, we demonstrate a more successful size-dependent extraction and separation of a particle mixture by using a mixed solution comprising Na-acetate (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 800 mM) and K-acetate (
c
L
= 0 M and
c
H
= 200 mM). The imposed electric fields of K- and Na-acetates are too strong and too weak, respectively, to separate the particle mixture. Therefore, we can easily estimate that the mixed solution of K- and Na-acetates is appropriate for the selective separation of smaller particles from the particle mixture. As shown in
Figure
3
c, all the 200 nm particles are completely extracted, while almost all the 620 nm particles are left in the target chamber by actively switching the concentration gradient, thereby demonstrating a dynamic transport control of colloidal particles on a chip. Notably, we demonstrate the benefits of the MNDP for the on-demand separation and/or fractionation of a particle mixture in a repeatable manner with another experimental set, as shown in
Movie S8
. We also quantitatively compared the motion of the two particle types in the absence and presence of the solute gradient, as shown in
Figure S8
. To quantify the number of the particles remaining in the target chamber, we analyzed particle distributions along the
x
-axis, as shown in
Figure S8e–h
, which were calculated from the fluorescence intensities in
Figure S8a–d
, respectively. We also calculated the removal and recovery rates of unwanted and target particles, respectively. Regarding the 200 nm particles, most particles were removed from the target chamber at removal rates of 96% and 92% for K-acetate and a mixture of K- and Na-acetates, respectively. In contrast, the 620 nm particles were recovered in the target chamber with recovery rates of 57% and 94% for K-acetate and the mixture of K- and Na-acetates, respectively. In the presence of the Na-acetate concentration gradient, both particles were fractionated without leaving the target chamber. However, in the absence of a concentration gradient, they left the target chamber without any separation.

It is still interesting that the smaller particles (i.e., 200 nm) always move faster and farther than the larger particles (i.e., 620 nm) for all the transient periods (i.e.,
t
< 5 min). These transient extraction processes seem to be contradictory to the tendency of other phoresis mechanisms, in which the migration speed (i.e., phoretic mobility) decreases with the particle size because of the scaling law.
(3,8,15,38)
As mentioned earlier, the classical theory of size-independent DP can be explained only with ζ
p
of particles and β of solutions, as plotted in
Figure
4
a. However, for the particles with similar ζ potential, the theory fails to explain the fast migration of the smaller particles compared to the migration of the larger ones. Therefore, we utilized the size-dependent Γ
EP
and Γ
CP
of particles to consider the size effect. Subsequently, these variables could be calculated using
eqs 4
and
5
, and then compared with the experimental results in the same sequential order, as shown in
Figure
3
. However, the significant modification of the net Γ
p
of particles by the manipulation of the β and ζ
p
values is of great importance. We note that various β values can easily be obtained by mixing two solutions with a fixed β value in different mixing ratios, as formulated in
Figure
4
a (inset). In addition, the ζ
p
of colloidal particles, potentially including biosamples, can be manipulated by using specific molecules, such as surfactants, as demonstrated earlier.

div.p:

of the submicron particles with a thin EDL (
κa
→ ∞) in the K-acetate, Na-acetate, and a mixture of K-acetate and Na-acetate solution, respectively. The inset shows the β values that can be obtained by mixing two solutions, such Na-acetate and K-acetate, in a different mixing ratio defined as
x
=
c

/(

Na-acetate
+ c
K-acetate
). Size-dependent Γ
p
of the particles in the (b) K-acetate solution and (c) Na-acetate solution. (d) The Γ
p
is modeled with respect to the particle size, β of solutions, and ζ
p
of particles.

div.div:
Figure
4
b shows the size-dependent Γ
p
with respect to λ for various ζ
p
values in the steady state. In the presence of the concentration gradient of K-acetate (β
K-acetate
= 0.285), by assuming κ
–1
= 3 nm for
c
= 10 mM and considering the size effect, we determined that the net Γ
p
is negative for the 200 nm particles (e.g., for
κa
≈ 33) and positive for the 620 nm particles (e.g., for
κa
≈ 103). This result indicates that the 200 nm particles migrate toward the low-concentration region, and the 620 nm particles circulate owing to the diffusioosmotic flow in the steady state. This is attributed to the fact that the relative contribution of EP is more significant than that of CP as the particle size decreases (i.e., when (
κa
)
−1
< 0.1). In other words, the magnitude of the Γ
p
of the 200 nm particles toward low concentration is greater than that of the 620 nm particles owing to the relatively large contribution of the EP; the suppression of CP is larger than that of EP. This theoretical model and description show a good agreement with the experimental results shown in
Figure
3
a.

Figure
4
c shows the net Γ
p
of the particles, calculated in the same manner, in the presence of the concentration gradient of Na-acetate (β
Na-acetate
= 0.101). In this case, the magnitude of Γ
CP
is much greater than that of Γ
EP
for both the 200 and 620 nm particles, resulting in their migration toward high concentration. As a result, the 620 nm particles return to the nanochannel faster than the 200 nm particles in the steady state. This also shows an excellent agreement with the experimental results shown in
Figure
3
b. Moreover, we confirmed that the theoretical models for the net Γ
p
in both K-acetate (
Figure
4
b) and Na-acetate (
Figure
4
c) show good agreement with the migration of single particle types, as shown in
Movie S9
. The experimental result in
Figure
3
c can also be explained in the same manner. As we optimized the strength of an induced electric field by mixing two solutions with different β values (i.e., the resulting β = 0.145), we could demonstrate that only the 200 nm particles are completely extracted while the 620 nm particles are left in the target chamber. This study reports on the empirical validation of the theoretical model to predict the size-dependent DP for particles in which the CP and EP are in opposite directions. Our experimental demonstration can be significant in developing nanoparticle separation and fractionation techniques. This is because the individual control of the magnitude and direction of CP and EP facilitates isolation of certain particle types from the mixture depending on the size or ζ potential. As it is possible to delicately adjust the magnitude and direction of net Γ
p
by mixing two common electrolyte solutions, this suggested mechanism would be valid for most submicron particles. The MNDP obviously facilitates the selection of the separation and fractionation modes of various submicron particles according to the simple formulation of buffer solutions.

Figure
4
d comprehensively shows the theoretical prediction of the β-dependent Γ
p
of submicron particles for various ζ
p
values in the steady state, thereby providing a well-established and powerful guideline for submicron particle separation and fractionation. As the Γ
p
is affected by the ζ potential, our technique is applicable to the separation of not only same-material particles with the same ζ
p
but also same-sized particles with different ζ
p
for submicron particles. To expand this separation mechanism to sub-100 nm particles, particle–particle interactions, such as stability issue and self-diffusion of nanoparticles, should be considered. Although the submicron particles used in this study were stable with high potential barrier energy according to Derjaguin–Landau–Verwey–Overbeek theory as shown in
Table S2
(refer to the Supplementary Theory and Modeling section in the
Supporting Information
for more information), the nanoparticles were very vulnerable to the irreversible aggregation in the high concentration of solutes. Therefore, the selection of the concentration level of solutes to drive nanoparticles by using diffusiophoretic force has limitations. Furthermore, the self-diffusion induced by the Brownian motion is one of the important transport phenomena dealing with nanoparticles. The Stokes–Einstein relation (
D
p
=
k
B
T
/6
πηa
) describes that the diffusion coefficient of colloidal particles increases as the particle size decreases. The diffusion coefficients of 200 nm (
D
p
= 2.45 μm
2
/s) and 620 nm (
D
p
= 0.79 μm
2
/s) particles are much smaller than the net Γ
p
, and thus, the self-diffusion was negligible in this study. However, the diffusion coefficient of nanoparticles (e.g., 50 nm particles,
D
p
= 9.8 μm
2
/s) could be comparable to the net Γ
p
; the isolation of certain nanoparticles in a DP-dominant environment is difficult due to the limited concentration gradient to avoid stability issues. Nevertheless, it would be possible to separate nanoparticles in a continuous flow in the absence of a preconcentration step that causes instability; this may require a new concept design of a micro-/nanofluidic device capable of manipulating the steady-state concentration gradient. Of course, the same approach could be applied to various biosamples requiring separation and/or fractionation on a chip; this is a topic for a future work.

It is worthwhile to discuss the other critical factors affecting the transport control of colloidal particles because the time-dependent competition of CP, EP, and DO is complex. First, the ζ potentials of the wall and particles clearly determine the diffusioosmotic and diffusiophoretic mobilities, respectively. The ζ potential of polymers is known to change significantly with ionic strength; therefore, the competition between CP and EP can be locally reversed along the target chamber, in which a very steep concentration gradient is formed. Second, the interdiffusion of multispecies ions may be useful for the transport control of colloidal particles; however, such a phenomenon has so far only been used to achieve constant osmolarity.
(22)
However, the target chamber of the MNDP is a semiopen channel with a two-way passage, comprising both the top main channel and nanochannel, which produces a two-sided nonlinear concentration gradient for existing solutes during buffer changes. Accordingly, the newly introduced solutes can enhance the electric field compared to that produced by the single-solute gradient. As a result, the interdiffusion between ionic species may contribute to the acceleration of the preconcentrated particle transport, especially early in the transient stage of the buffer change near the nanochannel. Currently, no study has provided an exact theory to explain the aforementioned factors, and thus more research is required to unveil the unknown dynamics of particles, such as sub-100 nm nanoparticles, in a complex physicochemical environment.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In summary, we developed the nanochannel-integrated, PDMS-based, and membrane-free MNDP to study the DP mechanism in which EP and CP are coupled nonlinearly with each other by optimizing both cracking-assisted photolithography and modified soft-lithography. We demonstrated that the MNDP, in which nanochannel functions as a porous membrane for the delicate diffusion control of solutes, made it possible to decouple the effect of EP and CP on the resulting DP of colloidal particles by generating stable and long-term concentration gradients in a transient or steady-state manner, facilitating the DP-based dynamic transport control of colloidal particles in the target chamber by only using a pipet. We further demonstrated that the MNDP allows the active switching of the spatiotemporal concentration gradients in the middle of device operation, resulting in the separation and fractionation of submicron particles according to their size or ζ potential by individually manipulating the relative strength of EP and CP, respectively. Furthermore, this study using the MNDP in conjunction with experimental results validates the theoretical model for predicting the size-dependent DP of particles in which the CP and EP are in opposite directions. We even showed the potential of the MNDP for submicron-particle separation and fractionation on a chip by varying several engineering factors, such as buffer conditions comprising the diffusivity difference between anions and cations, ζ potential of particles and channel walls that can be engineered using specific molecules/chemicals, and an interdiffusion phenomenon that requires additional research.

It is expected that the DP-based MNDP can be further used for the active transport control of various biosamples including selective concentration and exclusive separation based on sample features such as physical size and electrical charge density. In particular, the presented MNDP can be exploited as a portable, self-containable on-site μTAS that relies only on the chemical energies of solutions loaded into and flushed from the platform. Therefore, the aforementioned transport control mechanisms and/or techniques decrease the complexity, size, and cost of the overall system, enhance its portability, and facilitate its operability by further miniaturizing the essential transport control part of the μTAS.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
An SU-8 photoresist (SU-8 2010, MicroChem, Newton, MA) was adopted to fabricate a master mold. Polyurethane acrylate (PUA, MINS-311RM) and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) films (Minuta Tech, Osan, Gyeonggi, Korea) were used to replicate negative micro-/nanopatterns of the master mold. In addition, chlorotrimethylsilane (Sigma-Aldrich, Yongin, Gyeonggi, Korea) was used to silanize the surface of the replicated positive PUA mold. Further, polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS, Sylgard 184 silicone elastomer kit, Dow Corning, Midland, MI) and an extra-hard PDMS (X-PDMS) were then cast to produce a micro-/nanofluidic chip.
(39)
All chemicals used to prepare X-PDMS were purchased from JSI Silicone (Seongnam, Korea), including the linear vinyl siloxane (VDT-731), vinyl Q-siloxane (VQX-221), moderator (SIT 7900.0), platinum catalyst (SIP 6831.2LC), and linear hydride siloxane (HMS-501). Fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC, Sigma-Aldrich, Yongin, Gyeonggi, Korea) was prepared to visualize and quantify the rate of mass transport by dissolving it in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, Sigma-Aldrich, Yongin, Gyeonggi, Korea). Sodium chloride (NaCl), potassium chloride (KCl), potassium acetate (K-acetate), sodium acetate (Na-acetate), and Pluronic F-127 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. In addition, the fluorescent polystyrene latex particles, such as 1 μm carboxylated polystyrene labeled with Rhodamine-B, 620 nm polystyrene labeled with FITC, and 200 nm polystyrene labeled with Rhodamine-B, were purchased from Thermo Fisher. The Rhodamine-labeled particles are called
red ones
, while the FITC-labeled particles are called
blue ones
for convenience.

We adopted crack-photolithography developed in our previous study to obtain a mixed-scale micro-/nanofluidic device mold.
(31,32)
The cracking-induced nanopatterns/nanochannel were replicated using a PET film and PUA solution. A custom-made nitrogen chamber was used to minimize the effects of oxygen inhibition on the photocuring of the PUA solution. To resolve the roof-collapse problem and improve the mold reusability, we improved soft-lithography by using a PDMS composite comprising stacked triple layers of PDMS and X-PDMS. Regular PDMS was first spin-coated at 3000 rpm onto the replicated PUA mold and cured in a hot oven at 65 °C for 20 min. This was followed by the fabrication of the bilayer structure of PDMS and X-PDMS.
(39)
The prepared X-PDMS solution was used to spin-coat the PDMS–PUA mold at 1000 rpm, followed by heating at 65 °C for 15 min in the oven. Lastly, regular PDMS was poured onto the X-PDMS layer and cured at 65 °C for at least 4 h. Subsequently, the PDMS surfaces and a glass substrate were treated with oxygen plasma (20 sccm, 50 W for 30 s) to yield hydrophilic surfaces with a strong and irreversible bonding.

Optical and fluorescent images were obtained using an inverted fluorescence microscope (IX-71, Olympus) equipped with a charge-coupled device (CCD) camera (Clara, Andor, Belfast, Northern Ireland). The fluorescence intensities (FIs) of their results were plotted using ImageJ (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD) and OriginPro 2015 software (OriginLab Corp., Northampton, MA). The dimensions of the nanochannels were quantified using atomic force microscopy (D3100, Veeco), and oxygen plasma was introduced to bond the PDMS surfaces and a glass substrate (Cute-MP, Femto Science, Hwaseong, Korea). Further, a syringe pump (Harvard Apparatus, Holliston, MA) was used to characterize the inhibition effect of the advection flow through the nanochannel. The ζ potentials of the polystyrene particles were measured using a Zetasizer instrument (Nano-ZS, Malvern Panalytical).

Carboxylated polystyrene particles were dispersed in various ionic solutions, such as NaCl and KCl, with the final concentration of 0.05% w/v to demonstrate the accumulation of negatively charged particles. For colloidal particle accumulation, the concentration gradient of NaCl and KCl was produced by injecting a high solute concentration into the bottom source channel and a low solute concentration into the top main channel. The target chamber was also filled with the low solute concentration, which was subsequently replaced with the particle solution. After sample enrichment, the particle solution was replaced with pure distilled water. Subsequently, the high solute concentration in the source channel was changed to high-concentration K-acetate to extract the preconcentrated particles, unless otherwise noted. For the separation of a nanoparticle mixture, polystyrene particles with diameters of 200 and 620 nm were mixed with a 1:1 ratio to form the final concentration of 0.05% w/v. All particle solutions were treated with sonication for 30 min before being injected into the micro-/nanofluidic device. Further, all solutions were handled with a pipet to maintain flow rates during the desired working time, except in the experiment involving a syringe pump, to characterize the inhibition effect for the advection flow through the nanochannel. All initial images of each experiment were acquired as soon as the solution in the bottom source channel was changed.

The authors have developed a highly efficient microfluidic sample preconcn. device based on the electrokinetic trapping mechanism enabled by nanofluidic filters. The device, fabricated by std. photolithog. and etching techniques, generates an extended space charge region within a microchannel, which was used to both collect and trap the mols. efficiently. The electrokinetic trapping and collection can be maintained for several hours, and concn. factors as high as 106-108 have been demonstrated. This device could be useful in various bioanal. microsystems, due to its simplicity, performance, robustness, and integrability to other sepn. and detection systems.

A novel method, free flow acoustophoresis (FFA), capable of continuous sepn. of mixed particle suspensions into multiple outlet fractions is presented. Acoustic forces are utilized to sep. particles based on their size and d. The method is shown to be suitable for both biol. and nonbiol. suspended particles. The microfluidic sepn. chips were fabricated using conventional microfabrication methods. Particle sepn. was accomplished by combining laminar flow with the axial acoustic primary radiation force in an ultrasonic standing wave field. Dissimilar suspended particles flowing through the 350-μm-wide channel were thereby laterally translated to different regions of the laminar flow profile, which was split into multiple outlets for continuous fraction collection. Using four outlets, a mixt. of 2-, 5-, 8-, and 10-μm polystyrene particles was sepd. with between 62 and 94% of each particle size ending up in sep. fractions. Using three outlets and three particle sizes (3, 7, and 10 μm) the corresponding results ranged between 76 and 96%. It was also proven possible to sep. normally acoustically inseparable particle types by manipulating the d. of the suspending medium with cesium chloride. The medium manipulation, in combination with FFA, was further used to enable the fractionation of red cells, platelets, and leukocytes. The results show that free flow acoustophoresis can be used to perform complex sepn. tasks, thereby offering an alternative to expensive and time-consuming methods currently in use.

Bhagat, Ali Asgar S.; Hou, Han Wei; Li, Leon D.; Lim, Chwee Teck; Han, Jongyoon

Blood is a highly complex bio-fluid with cellular components making up >40% of the total vol., thus making its anal. challenging and time-consuming. In this work, we introduce a high-throughput size-based sepn. method for processing dild. blood using inertial microfluidics. The technique takes advantage of the preferential cell focusing in high aspect-ratio microchannels coupled with pinched flow dynamics for isolating low abundance cells from blood. As an application of the developed technique, we demonstrate the isolation of cancer cells (circulating tumor cells (CTCs)) spiked in blood by exploiting the difference in size between CTCs and hematol. cells. The microchannel dimensions and processing parameters were optimized to enable high throughput and high resoln. sepn., comparable to existing CTC isolation technologies. Results from expts. conducted with MCF-7 cells spiked into whole blood indicate >80% cell recovery with an impressive 3.25 × 105 fold enrichment over red blood cells (RBCs) and 1.2 × 104 fold enrichment over peripheral blood leukocytes (PBL). In spite of a 20× sample diln., the fast operating flow rate allows the processing of ∼108 cells min-1 through a single microfluidic device. The device design can be easily customized for isolating other rare cells from blood including peripheral blood leukocytes and fetal nucleated red blood cells by simply varying the pinching' width. The advantage of simple label-free sepn., combined with the ability to retrieve viable cells post enrichment and minimal sample pre-processing presents numerous applications for use in clin. diagnosis and conducting fundamental studies.

The screening and isolation of target microorganisms from mutated recombinant libraries are crucial for the advancement of synthetic biol. and metabolic engineering. However, conventional screening tools present several limitations in throughput, cost, and labor. Herein, we describe a novel microfluidic high-throughput screening (HTS) platform with several advantages. The platform utilizes a fluid array to compartmentalize bacterial cells in well-ordered sepd. microwells and allows long-term cell culture with high throughput. The platform enables the extn. of selected target cells from the fluid array for addnl. culture and postanal. by using a capillary-driven sample relocation method. To confirm the feasibility of the platform, we demonstrated two different types of HTS methods based on the levels of reporter gene expression and cellular growth rate difference. For the reporter gene-based HTS, a spike recovery approach was taken to demonstrate that target cells are successfully screened out from a mixt. contg. nontarget cells by repeating the culture and extn. processes. Addnl., the same platform allowed us to screen and sort target cells according to their cellular growth rate difference, which seems hard in conventional screening methods. A rapid, paper microfluidic- and smartphone-based protocol was developed for the extn. and direct fluorescent identification of the nucleic acids of Salmonella Typhimurium from field and clin. samples. Initially, liq. samples (10% dild.) from fresh poultry packaging were loaded on the paper chips and were lysed with Tris-EDTA (TE) buffer. Nucleic acids from the lysed samples were eluted through the paper channel with TE buffer and the paper channel was excised into three pieces for the further polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay. The extn. efficiency was detd. by measuring fluorescence reflectance with either a benchtop optical detection system (consisting of an LED light source, a pair of optical fibers, and a miniature spectrophotometer, all built on micro-positioning stages) or a smartphone-based fluorescent microscope (inhouse fabricated). The limit of detection of Salmonella Typhimurium in 10% poultry packaging liq. with cellulose paper was 103 CFU mL-1, while that extd. with nitrocellulose paper was 104 CFU mL-1 (as detd. by both PCR and fluorescence reflectance). Cellulose channels proved more appropriate for measuring low and very high concns. of pathogen DNA, while nitrocellulose proved better for analyzing the mid-range concns. We obsd. that DNA migrated through nitrocellulose at a faster rate and further than through cellulose due to charge-charge repulsion between nitrocellulose and DNA (both neg. charged), thus contributing to consistent and efficient extn. We tested the efficiency of Salmonella extn. from 10% poultry packaging liq., 10% whole blood, and 10% fecal samples, and obtained comparable extn. efficiency, as confirmed by smartphone-based direct fluorescent detection. This protocol is suitable for the direct detection of total bacteria count in a dirty sample (when specificity is not necessary) as well as detg. extn. efficiency. This protocol is compatible with PCR, to provide specific information about the type of pathogen present in sample.

A novel DC-dielectrophoresis (DEP) method employing a pressure-driven flow for the continuous sepn. of micro/nano-particles is presented in this paper. To generate the DEP force, a small voltage difference is applied to produce a non-uniformity of the elec. field across a microchannel via a larger orifice of several hundred microns on one side of the channel wall and a smaller orifice of several hundred nanometers on the opposite channel wall. The particles experience a DEP force when they move with the flow through the vicinity of the small orifice, where the strongest elec. field gradient exists. Expts. were conducted to demonstrate the sepn. of 1μm and 3μm polystyrene particles by size by adjusting the applied elec. potentials. In order to sep. smaller nanoparticles, the elec. cond. of the suspending soln. is adjusted so that the polystyrene nanoparticles of a given size experience pos. DEP while the polystyrene nanoparticles of another size experience neg. DEP. Using this method, the sepn. of 51 nm and 140 nm nanoparticles and the sepn. of 140 nm and 500 nm nanoparticles were demonstrated. In comparison with the microfluidic DC-DEP methods reported in the literature which utilize hurdles or obstacles to induce the non-uniformity of an elec. field, a pair of asym. orifices on the channel side walls is used in this method to generate a strong elec. field gradient and has advantages such as capability of sepg. nanoparticles, and locally applied lower elec. voltages to minimize the Joule heating effect.

Sepns. represent a fundamental unit operation in biol. and biotechnol. Commensurate with their importance is the diversity of methods that have been developed for performing them. One important class of sepns. are equil. gradient methods, wherein a medium with some type of spatial nonuniformity is combined with a force field to focus particles to equil. positions related to those particles' intrinsic properties. A second class of techniques that is nonequil. exploits labels to sort particles based upon their extrinsic properties. While equil. techniques such as iso-elec. focusing (IEF) have become instrumental within anal. chem. and proteomics, cell sepns. predominantly rely upon the second, label-based class of techniques, exemplified by fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) and magnetic-activated cell sorting (MACS). To extend the equil. techniques available for sepg. cells, we demonstrate the first implementation of a new microfluidic equil. sepn. method, which we call isodielec. sepn. (IDS), for sorting cells based upon elec. distinguishable phenotypes. IDS is analogous to isoelec. focusing, except instead of sepg. amphoteric mols. in a pH gradient using electrophoresis, we sep. cells and particles in an elec. cond. gradient using dielectrophoresis. IDS leverages many of the advantages of microfluidics and equil. gradient sepn. methods to create a device that is continuous-flow, capable of parallel sepns. of multiple (>2) subpopulations from a heterogeneous background, and label-free. We demonstrate the sepn. of polystyrene beads based upon surface conductance as well as sorting nonviable from viable cells of the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

Techniques that can dexterously manipulate single particles, cells, and organisms are invaluable for many applications in biol., chem., engineering, and physics. Here, we demonstrate standing surface acoustic wave based "acoustic tweezers" that can trap and manipulate single microparticles, cells, and entire organisms (i.e., Caenorhabditis elegans) in a single-layer microfluidic chip. Our acoustic tweezers utilize the wide resonance band of chirped interdigital transducers to achieve real-time control of a standing surface acoustic wave field, which enables flexible manipulation of most known microparticles. The power d. required by our acoustic device is significantly lower than its optical counterparts (10,000,000 times less than optical tweezers and 100 times less than optoelectronic tweezers), which renders the technique more biocompatible and amenable to miniaturization. Cell-viability tests were conducted to verify the tweezers' compatibility with biol. objects. With its advantages in biocompatibility, miniaturization, and versatility, the acoustic tweezers presented here will become a powerful tool for many disciplines of science and engineering.

A review. Optical trapping and manipulation of micrometer-sized particles was first reported in 1970. Since then, it has been successfully implemented in two size ranges: the subnanometer scale, where light-matter mech. coupling enables cooling of atoms, ions and mols., and the micrometer scale, where the momentum transfer resulting from light scattering allows manipulation of microscopic objects such as cells. But it has been difficult to apply these techniques to the intermediate - nanoscale - range that includes structures such as quantum dots, nanowires, nanotubes, graphene and two-dimensional crystals, all of crucial importance for nanomaterials-based applications. Recently, however, several new approaches have been developed and demonstrated for trapping plasmonic nanoparticles, semiconductor nanowires and carbon nanostructures. Here, the authors review the state-of-the-art in optical trapping at the nanoscale, with an emphasis on some of the most promising advances, such as controlled manipulation and assembly of individual and multiple nanostructures, force measurement with femtonewton resoln., and biosensors.

Manipulating DNA translocation through nanopore is one crucial requirement for new ultrafast sequencing methods in the sense that the polymers have to be denatured, unraveled, and then propelled through the pore with very low speed. Here we propose and theor. explore a novel design to fulfill the demands by utilizing cross-pore thermal gradient. The high temp. in the cis reservoir is expected to transform double-stranded DNA into single strands and that temp. would also prevent those single strands from intrastrand base-pairing, thus, achieving favorable polymer conformation for the subsequent translocation and sequencing. Then, the substantial temp. drop across the pore caused by the thermal-insulating membrane sepg. cis and trans chambers would stimulate thermophoresis of the mols. through nanopores. Our theor. evaluation shows that the DNA translocation speeds will be orders smaller than the electrophoretic counterpart, while high capture rate of DNA into nanopore is maintained, both of which would greatly benefit the sequencing.

Collective effects on thermophoresis of aq. particle suspensions are studied exptl. and theor. A microfluidic device is used to characterize thermophoretic transport of 100 nm, 500 nm and 1 μm particles of various concns. in deionized (DI) water. Our exptl. findings show two interesting collective effects on the Soret coeff. of colloids: (i) for smaller particles (e.g., 100 nm and 500 nm), a sign change of the Soret coeff. is obsd. when increasing the particle concn.; (ii) for larger particles (e.g., 1 μm), a neg. Soret coeff. is always seen. A model is derived to account for the collective effect on the thermophoresis of colloids using the well-known Derjaguin-Landau-Verwey-Overbeek (DLVO) theory that combines the van der Waals (VDW) attraction and the elec. double layer (EDL) repulsion. Such DLVO interactions in an inhomogeneous particle suspension can exert an addnl. force on particles and thus modify the mass transport of particles under both temp. and concn. gradients and also alter the corresponding Soret coeff. It is found that the proposed theor. model can favorably explain our exptl. observations.

Transport rates of 0.1 μ diam. polystyrene latex spheres through porous membrane sepg. solns. differing in electrolyte concn. were measured to det. the diffusiophoretic velocities of the particles. Two types of expts. were performed. In the first, the initial particle concn. was the same on both sides of the membrane; after an electrolyte concn. difference was created, the accumulation of particles on one side and the depletion on the other side were measured as functions of time. These expts. demonstrate the phenomenon of diffusiophoresis; there is no other obvious explanation for the formation of a particle gradient from a system initially uniform in particle concn. In the second type of expt., particles were placed only on one side of the membrane, and the electrolyte gradient was established such that it augmented the particle transport rate down the particle concn. gradient. Enhancements of 50 times Brownian diffusion of the particles were obsd. when there was a 70% change in electrolyte concn. across the membrane. The expts. were performed with membranes of different pore size, and the results were extrapolated to infinite pore size to obtain the diffusiophoretic velocity of the particles in free soln. Comparison between these exptl. velocities and theor. predictions shows very good agreement when the electrolyte was MCl (M = Li, Na, K) in the concn. range 0.01-0.1 M. Particle fluxes (based on pore area) decreased as pore size decreased, as expected from a model based on steric and charge repulsion from the pore wall. The exptl. velocities for diffusiophoresis in gradients of KOAc were an order of magnitude greater than predicted from theory; this discrepancy might be due to a large uncertainty in the theor. prediction for this electrolyte.

Brownian diffusion is a keystone concept in a large variety of domains, from physics, chem. to biol. Diffusive transport controls situations as diverse as reaction-diffusion processes in biol. and chem., Brownian ratchet processes, dispersion in microfluidic devices or even double-diffusive instability and salt-fingering phenomena in the context of ocean mixing. Although these examples span a broad range of length scales, diffusive transport becomes increasingly inefficient for larger particles. Applications, for example, in microfluidics, usually have recourse to alternative driving methods involving external sources to induce and control migration. Here, it is demonstrated exptl. a strongly enhanced migration of large particles, achieved by slaving their dynamics to that of a fast carrier species, a dil. salt. The underlying fast salt diffusion leads to an apparent diffusive-like dynamics of the large particles, which is up to two orders of magnitude faster than their natural bare' diffusion. Moreover both spreading and focusing of the particle assembly can be achieved on demand. A model description shows a remarkable quant. agreement with all measured data. Applications of this process are illustrated in microfluidics for filtering and concg. operations, as well as in conjunction with std. hydrodynamic focusing. In a wider perspective, this mechanism can affect a broad range of scales and phenomena, from biol. transport to the dispersion of sediments and pollutants in oceanog. situations.

Dead-end micro- and nanoscale channels are ubiquitous in nature and are found in geol. and biol. systems subject to frequent disruptions. Achieving fluid flows in them is not possible through conventional pressure-driven mechanisms. Here we show that chem. driven convective flows leading to transport in and out of dead-end pores can occur by the phenomenon of "transient diffusioosmosis". The advective velocity depends on the presence of an in situ-generated transient ion gradient and the intrinsic charge on the pore wall. The flows can reach speeds of 50 μm/s and cause extn. of otherwise-trapped materials. Our results illustrate that chem. energy, in the form of a transient salt gradient, can be transduced into mech. motion with the pore wall acting as the pump. As discussed, the phenomena may underlie obsd. transport in many geol. and biol. systems involving tight or dead-end micro- and nanochannels.

Transport of colloids in dead-end channels is involved in widespread applications including drug delivery and underground oil and gas recovery. In such geometries, Brownian motion may be considered as the sole mechanism that enables transport of colloidal particles into or out of the channels, but it is, unfortunately, an extremely inefficient transport mechanism for microscale particles. Here, we explore the possibility of diffusiophoresis as a means to control the colloid transport in dead-end channels by introducing a solute gradient. We demonstrate that the transport of colloidal particles into the dead-end channels can be either enhanced or completely prevented via diffusiophoresis. In addn., we show that size-dependent diffusiophoretic transport of particles can be achieved by considering a finite Debye layer thickness effect, which is commonly ignored. A combination of diffusiophoresis and Brownian motion leads to a strong size-dependent focusing effect such that the larger particles tend to conc. more and reside deeper in the channel. Our findings have implications for all manners of controlled release processes, esp. for site-specific delivery systems where localized targeting of particles with minimal dispersion to the nontarget area is essential.

The terminal velocity is calcd. of a nonconductive sphere through a slightly nonuniform soln. of a sym. charged, binary electrolyte. The anal. proceeds through an expansion in the small parameter λ (the ratio of the counterion-cloud thickness to the particle radius). Results to O(λ) are presented. The only property of the sphere's surface that affects the velocity is its zeta potential, ζ, when the electrolyte gradient vanishes; no information concerning the dependence of ζ upon ionic strength is needed. While the chemiphoretic effect always directs the particle toward higher electrolyte concn., the electrophoretic contribution can move the particle in either direction depending on the sign of βζ, where β is a normalized difference in mobilities between the cation and anion of the electrolyte; thus particle movement can be directed toward either higher or lower electrolyte concn. depending on the phys. properties. With slight algebraic rearrangement, the results are applicable to conventional electrophoresis (particle motion in an applied elec. field) and show excellent agreement with the numerical calcns. of R. W. O'Brien and L. R. White (1978).

A review. Fluid transport that is driven by gradients of pressure, gravity, or electro-magnetic potential is well-known and studied in many fields. A subtler type of transport, called diffusiophoresis, occurs in a gradient of chem. concn., either electrolyte or non-electrolyte. Diffusiophoresis works by driving a slip velocity at the fluid-solid interface. Although the mechanism is well-known, the diffusiophoresis mechanism is often considered to be an esoteric lab. phenomenon. However, in this article we show that concn. gradients can develop in a surprisingly wide variety of phys. phenomena - imposed gradients, asym. reactions, dissoln., crystn., evapn., mixing, sedimentation, and others - so that diffusiophoresis is in fact a very common transport mechanism, in both natural and artificial systems. We anticipate that in georeservoir extns., physiol. systems, drying operations, lab. and industrial sepns., crystn. operations, membrane processes, and many other situations, diffusiophoresis is already occurring - often without being recognized - and that opportunities exist for designing this transport to great advantage.

In-line preconcentration techniques are used to improve the sensitivity of microfluidic DNA analysis platforms. The most common methods are electrokinetic and require an externally applied electric field. Here we describe a microfluidic DNA preconcentration technique that does not require an external field. Instead, pressure-driven flow from a fluid-filled microcapillary into a lower ionic strength DNA sample reservoir induces spontaneous DNA migration against the direction of flow. This migratory phenomenon that we call Molecular Rheotaxis initiates in seconds and results in a concentrated DNA bolus at the capillary orifice. We demonstrate the ease with which this concentration method can be integrated into a microfluidic total analysis system composed of in-line DNA preconcentration, size separation, and single-molecule detection. Paired experimental and numerical simulation results are used to delineate the parameters required to induce Molecular Rheotaxis, elucidate the underlying mechanism, and optimize conditions to achieve DNA concentration factors exceeding 10,000 fold.

The flow of solns. contg. solutes and colloidal particles in porous media is widely found in systems including underground aquifers, hydraulic fractures, estuarine or coastal habitats, water filtration systems, etc. In such systems, solute gradients occur when there is a local change in the solute concn. While the effects of solute gradients have been found to be important for many applications, we observe an unexpected colloidal behavior in porous media driven by the combination of solute gradients and the fluid flow. When two flows with different solute concns. are in contact near a junction, a sharp solute gradient is formed at the interface, which may allow strong diffusiophoresis of the particles directed against the flow. Consequently, the particles accumulate near the pore entrance, rapidly approaching the packing limit. These colloidal dynamics have important implications for the clogging of a porous medium, where particles that are orders of magnitude smaller than the pore width can accumulate and block the pores within a short period of time. We also show that this effect can be exploited as a useful tool for preconcg. biomols. for rapid bioassays.

It has been obsd. that colloidal particles are anomalously repelled from the interface of nanoporous materials and water by up to hundreds of micrometers even if there is no addnl. external field present. Recently, the phys. origin of this anomalous repulsion has turned out to be diffusiophoretic migration triggered by an ion exchange process through the interface. Since the repulsive force is induced by a salt gradient only, the phenomenon can be applied to a microscale water purifn. platform without the need for any external power sources. In this work, we suggest a micro/nanofluidic device for continuous water purifn. utilizing long-range diffusiophoretic migration around ion exchangeable surfaces. An ion concn. boundary layer was characterized by the Sherwood no. (Sh) which is a key dimensionless no. to describe the purifn. process. Depending on Sh, we have theor. and exptl. demonstrated that long-range diffusiophoretic exclusion can be used for continuous water purifn. Finally, our platform can be used as a highly energy-efficient and portable water treatment option for operations such as purifn., disinfection, water softening, etc.

Despite the unique advantages of nanochannels imparted by their small size, their utility is limited by the lack of affordable and versatile fabrication methods. Moreover, nanochannel-incorporated fluidic devices require micro-sized conduit integration for efficient access of liq. samples. In this study, a simple and cost-effective fabrication method for mixed-scale channel networks via hot-embossing of poly(Me methacrylate) (PMMA) using a carbon stamp is demonstrated. Due to its high rigidity, PMMA ensures collapse-free channel fabrication. The carbon stamp is fabricated using only batch microfabrication and has a convex architecture that allows the fabrication of a complex channel network via a single imprinting process. In addn., the microchannels are connected to nanochannels via three-dimensional (3D) microfunnels that serve as single-particle-entrapment chambers, ensuring smooth transport of samples into the nanochannels. Owing to the 3D geometry of the microfunnels and the small size of the nanochannels, a solute gradient can be generated locally at the microfunnel. This local solute gradient enables the entrapment of microparticles at the microfunnels via diffusiophoresis, which can manipulate the particle motion in a controllable manner, without any external equipment or addnl. electrode integration into the channels. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of diffusiophoresis-based single-particle entrapment.

Double layer forces acting between micron-sized silica particles are measured with the at. force microscope (AFM) in solns. of sym., multivalent electrolytes. In particular, the following 2:2 electrolytes, CuSO4, MgSO4, and the 3:3 electrolyte LaFe(CN)6 were investigated. For the multivalent electrolytes, the measured decay lengths are substantially larger than the ones expected on the basis of simple Debye-Huckel (DH) theory. These deviations can be explained quant. by the formation of neutral ion pairs. The measured surface charge d. decreases in magnitude with increasing valence. Both effects are caused by ion-ion correlations, which are not included in the classical DH theory. However, this theory remains applicable provided one considers the formation of ion pairs in soln. and an effective surface charge d. This effective charge is substantially smaller in magnitude than the one of the bare surface. This redn. results from adsorption of counterions, which becomes stronger with increasing valence. These observations reveal that DH theory is applicable even in the presence of multivalent ions, provided the effective parameters are chosen appropriately.

Cracks are obsd. in many environments, including walls, dried wood and even the Earth crust, and are often thought of as an unavoidable, unwanted phenomenon. Recent research advances have demonstrated the the ability to use cracks to produce various micro and nanoscale patterns. However, patterns are usually limited by the chosen substrate material and the applied tensile stresses. Here we describe an innovative cracking-assisted nanofabrication technique that relies only on a std. photolithog. process. This novel technique produces well-controlled nanopatterns in any desired shape and in a variety of geometric dimensions, over large areas and with a high throughput. Recent advances in controlling the cracking phenomena established a novel unconventional fabrication technique to generate mixed-scale patterns/structures with resoln. and accuracy comparable to conventional nanofabrication techniques. Here, the authors previous cracking-assisted nanofabrication technique (called crack-photolithog.) relying on only the std. photolithog. to develop micro/nanofluidic devices with greatly reduced time and cost is adapted. The crack-photolithog. makes it possible not only to simultaneously produce micropatterns and nanopatterns with various dimensions but also to replicate both of the mixed-scale patterns in a high-throughput manner. Therefore, a microfluidic channel network can easily be fabricated with a nanochannel array that can function as a nanoporous membrane wherever necessary, which basically plays a key role in diffusion-allowed but convection-suppressed microfluidic devices. In addn., the nanochannel array can manipulate the transport of small mols. by adjusting its dimension and/or no. at will, so that nanochannel-array-integrated micro/nanofluidic devices prove even more robust and accurate in diffusion control than conventional membrane-integrated microfluidic devices. As an application of such micro/nanofluidic devices, synthetic bacterial cells are employed and found that their genetic induction and expression are dominated by extracellular diffusive microenvironments that were completely engineered using the nanochannel array. Hence, the crack-photolithog. could provide innovative fabrication techniques for unprecedented micro/nanofluidic devices that show substantial potential for a wide range of biol. and chem. applications.

Diffusiophoresis in narrow channel flows
Ault, Jesse T.; Shin, Sangwoo; Stone, Howard A.
Journal of Fluid Mechanics
(
2018
),
854
(
),
420-448
CODEN:
JFLSA7
; ISSN:
0022-1120

(
Cambridge University Press
)
Flows contg. suspended colloidal particles and dissolved solutes are found in a multitude of natural and man-made systems including hydraulic fractures, water filtration systems and microfluidic devices, e.g. those designed for biol. or medical applications. In these types of systems, unexpected particle dynamics such as rapid particle transport and focusing has been obsd. in the presence of local solute gradients due to the cooperating or competing effects of fluid advection and particle diffusiophoresis, the latter driven by local chem. gradients. We develop anal. expressions for the fluid, solute and particle dynamics in long, narrow channels due to the combined influence of pressure-driven channel flow with diffusiophoretic and diffusioosmotic effects. The results confirm a rapid particle focusing effect that can be controlled by manipulating the particle, solute and flow properties, as well as the channel's geometry and surface chem. Thus, we propose a new approach for performing microfluidic zeta potentiometry, as well as techniques for sorting, concg. and/or capturing particles based on their sizes or zeta potentials. Finally, we demonstrate that diffusioosmotic effects can be used to pump fluid against a pressure gradient.

Characterization of surface-solute interactions by diffusioosmosis
Ault, Jesse T.; Shin, Sangwoo; Stone, Howard A.

(

),

(

Royal Society of Chemistry

The accurate measurement of wall zeta potentials and solute-surface interaction length scales for electrolyte and non-electrolyte solutes, resp., is crit. to the design of many biomedical and microfluidic applications. We present a novel microfluidic approach using diffusioosmosis for measuring either the zeta potentials or the characteristic interaction length scales for surfaces exposed to, resp., electrolyte or non-electrolyte solutes. When flows contg. different solute concns. merge in a junction, local solute concn. gradients can drive diffusioosmotic flow due to electrokinetic, steric, and other interactions between the solute mols. and solid surfaces. We demonstrate a microfluidic system consisting of a long, narrow pore connecting two large side channels in which solute concn. gradients drive diffusioosmosis within the pore, resulting in predictable fluid velocity/pressure and solute profiles. Furthermore, we present anal. results and a methodol. to det. the zeta potential or interaction length scale for the pore surfaces based on the solute concns. in the main side channels, the flow rate in the pore, and the pressure drop across the pore. We apply this method to the exptl. data of Lee et al. to predict the zeta potentials of their system, and we use 3D numerical simulations to validate the theory and show that end effects caused by the junctions are negligible for a wide range of parameters. Because the dynamics in the proposed system are driven by diffusioosmosis, this technique does not suffer from certain disadvantages assocd. with the use of sensitive electronics in traditional zeta potential measurement approaches such as streaming potential, streaming current, or electroosmosis. To the best of our knowledge this is the first flow-based approach to characterize surface/solute interactions with non-electrolyte solutes.

The size redn. and surface charge modification of carbon black particles aq. dispersions by cationic surfactant, cetyltrimethylammonium chloride (CTAC), and amphiphilic polymer, polystyrene-polyethylene oxide (PS-PEO) are described. Aq. and vacuum dried carbon black dispersions contg. various amts. of CTAC surfactant or PS-PEO copolymer were analyzed by dynamic light scattering, microelectrophoresis and by transmission electron microscopy. In presence of CTAC and PS-PEO additives, the final carbon particle sizes in aq. dispersions were in the range 170-230 nm, whereas in vacuum dried dispersions, the achieved particle sizes were in the range 327-372 nm. Blank expts. made in absence of surfactant and copolymer gave carbon black particles mean sizes of 330 and 470 nm, resp., in aq. and vacuum dried dispersions. Further, in presence of PS-PEO copolymer, the magnitude of zeta potential was reduced from -50 to -18 mV, whereas in presence of CTAC surfactant, the sign of zeta potential was reversed from neg. to pos. and its magnitude decreased from -50 to +35 mV. Beyond the size redn. and the surface charge modification of carbon particles by CTAC surfactant and PS-PEO copolymer, the prepn. mode of carbon dispersions was also found to affect the carbon particle properties. The overall data are explained in term of the nature of interactions occurring at carbon-aq. soln. interface. The knowledge of such interactions is the prerequisite to prevent the aggregation of carbon particles either in soln. or in polymeric matrix.

Dispersion of carbon black powders in aq. medium was investigated by using anionic surfactant sodium oleate and a series of nonionic surfactants which were selected systematically to represent varying degrees of ethoxylation. Single and binary mixts. of the nonionic and ionic surfactants were employed in zeta potential and particle size measurements and a high affinity of surfactants on carbon black powders was beheld as they significantly changed the zeta potential and size distribution of the powders. But, noticeable differences between the surfactants were also obsd., for example, as the nonionic surfactants reduced the abs. magnitude of zeta potential of powders in a wide pH range of 3.0-11.0, Na oleate made the zeta potential of the powders more neg. under similar exptl. conditions. The carbon black suspensions were agitated in a vessel having a std. geometry and the particle size measurements were carried out at desired time intervals without disturbance of the suspensions and interruption of agitation. Effect of surfactants on stability and dispersion of the powders were recognized with the redn. in mean particle sizes, as, in the absence of surfactant, the mean particle size could not be reduced below 24.0 μm even after 210 min of stirring, it could be reduced to 5.35 μm after 120 min of stirring in the presence of only 30 g/L of nonionic surfactant. Generally, it was found that nonionic surfactants could wet and stabilize carbon black powders in aq. medium better than anionic surfactant. The reason was explained by mol. structure and bulk properties of surfactants.
